title: 110_s2784
content: The Howard M. Metzenbaum ``Menu Education and Labeling Act'' or the ``MEAL Act'' is the short title of this legislation. Congress acknowledges the strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the rise in obesity rates in the United States, with two-thirds of American adults being overweight or obese. Obesity poses risks such as diabetes, heart disease, and cancer, costing the US $117 billion annually. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and half of food dollars spent on restaurant food. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the US. Heart disease costs $142 billion annually in healthcare and lost productivity. Increased sodium intake is linked to high blood pressure. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires food manufacturers to provide nutrition information on packaged foods, but restaurant foods are exempt unless a nutrient content or health claim is made. Approximately 75% of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Consumers want nutrition information at restaurants to make informed decisions about their food choices, as studies show it can influence their purchasing decisions. Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend increased availability of nutrition information to reduce obesity rates. SEC. 3. NUTRITION LABELING OF STANDARD MENU ITEMS AT CHAIN RESTAURANTS. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include regulations for restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name. The amendment requires restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name to disclose calorie, fat, and sodium content of standard food servings on menus or equivalent means as specified by the Secretary. The amendment mandates that restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations must display calorie, fat, and sodium content of standard food servings on menus or equivalent means as specified by the Secretary. Additionally, they must provide clear and conspicuous nutrition information to help the public understand the significance of the information provided. The amendment requires restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations to display calorie, fat, and sodium content on menus or equivalent means. It also mandates clear and conspicuous nutrition information for public understanding. The clause does not apply to certain food items not listed on menus or daily specials specified by the Secretary. The amendment mandates restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations to display calorie, fat, and sodium content on menus or equivalent means. It also requires clear nutrition information for public understanding. Self-service facilities must have signs listing calories per standard serving. Restaurants can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with regulations. The amendment requires restaurants with 20 or more locations to display calorie, fat, and sodium content on menus. State or local requirements can also mandate additional nutrition information. The Secretary must propose regulations within a year to accommodate variations in serving sizes and food preparation. The Secretary must propose regulations within a year to accommodate variations in serving sizes and food preparation, including inadvertent human error and training of food service workers. Final regulations must be promulgated within 2 years of enactment, or proposed regulations will become effective. The final regulations for vending machines, as outlined in item (I), will become effective the day after the date of enactment. The Secretary is required to publish a notice of these regulations in the Federal Register. Vending machine operators with 20 or more machines must provide a conspicuous sign for food items that cannot be examined before purchase. The vending machine operator with 20 or more machines must display a sign disclosing the calorie content of the items. Additionally, they can voluntarily provide more nutrition information as long as it complies with the requirements. State or local regulations regarding nutrition information for vending machines are not precluded by this clause. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to implement the requirement for vending machine operators to provide nutrition information. State or local regulations on nutrition information are allowed. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years to implement the requirement for vending machine operators to provide nutrition information. If the Secretary fails to finalize regulations within the specified timeframe, the proposed regulations will automatically become effective as final regulations, and the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register.
